Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2008 08:45AM TXBadboob wrote:     Hi, Lori and Gina,     I was starting to wonder if I was the only one on Abraxane.  I don't see much about it on here.  My onco told me it's a little more expensive, so they have to fight the insurance on it, so I figure that's why it seems rare.  I'm going to let you know what I've been through so far.  Hope this helps.     I am on my 8th weekly Abraxane treatment so far.  My side effects have been neuropathy in my fingers, toes, and sometimes my tongue.  It feels like I have been burned but not bad.  Sometimes I feel like I'm burning inside also, and just every once in a while I feel nauseous.  My onco gave me meds for that. Also my face and neck burn sometimes, and a while back my face broke out in a rash like acne.  I tried different moisturizers and even hydrocortisone, but it only got worse, so now I only wash my face with aveeno sensitive wash, and I only moisturize my eyes, and it is better.  I have bone pain sometimes from the neupogen shot I get the day after chemo.  Sometimes it's kinda bad, but mostly not too bad.  I have been able to keep working, but I work with my hands, so I hope it doesn't get worse.     I only have four more treatments to go and then I start FEC for the next three months every three weeks, which they tell me will make me sicker and more tired than the Abraxane, but not the neuropathy.  I'm so tired of the burning fingers, it gets to you sometimes.  My nails hurt, too, but they haven't fallen off like they said they might.     I get real depressed sometimes, but I think it might just be the chemo.  I definitly have the chemo brain.  I think it's made me dyslectic.  You wouldn't believe how long it took me to type this reply:)      Gina, I live south of Houston, and I get my treatments there, too.      I hope this helps ya'll.  Sorry if I run on a bit.  I'm saying a prayer for both of you right now.

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2009 04:42AM TXBadboob wrote: sharebear,   I also did my first Zometa IV in July.  They want me to do it every 2 mos.   I want to warn you if they haven't already, get ALL of your dental work done BEFORE you get the Zometa!  There is a small chance of jaw necrosis that can be a SE of Zometa.  I needed some dental work before I had it, and now I'm having to do some very expensive laser dental because you can't have extractions of teeth or cutting on your tissue that can get infected.  So what would have cost me about 300.- 400.00, is now costing me 5000.00 in all.  Just make sure you tell your dentist that you are on Zometa.  It is important for them to know.   It is just a small chance, but one I wasn't willing to take after I saw pictures of it.  I will still take the Zometa, because of my osteopenia and the 50% chance of no recurrence!  Isn't it wonderful about the new drugs they're finding now to help us.  I'm sorry you're having to go through this again and my prayers are with you. Deen

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2009 08:00AM TXBadboob wrote: Three mos of Abraxane caused my neuropathy, followed by 3 mos of FEC, which I think prolonged the problem.  So I have been off chemo for 2 mos, and I still have the numbness in my fingertips, I think my nails will still take a few months to grow out the "tree rings" effects.  I didn't lose any nails, but I kept them super short and worked with gauze tape on my fingers.  I thought I was out of the woods with my toenails, went for a pedicure a month after chemo, and now my toenails are coming up like my fingernails did.  I actually have an ingrown nail on my right foot because of it:(  Sat night it was very painful, and I used my lidocaine on it to get back to sleep.  I've been babying it carefully to avoid infection.  So last night I talked to my stepmom, and she informs me she just had her big toe amputated last week because infection in her bone from an ingrown toenail!  Whoa!  So, I'm going to the Dr Friday and I'll have him look at it, though I think it's getting better.   Looks like it will take a long time to get over this, just like everything else with this #%$^ disease! Deen

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2009 10:30PM TXBadboob wrote: Hi Michelle,   I'm sorry, I didn't have the mx and oopher/hyster at the same time, but I had my exchange and oopher/hysterectomy at the same time.  The abdomen area was quite sore, but not even bad enough for pain pills, and the incisions were tiny(laproscopic).  The exchange was also no big deal, except the nauseau after surgery.   My mx itself was quite a bit harder.  In the hospital two days, had to sleep sitting up on a big pillow for about four weeks, and I took pain pills as necessary.  Don't be afraid to take them, they will help a lot.  I went back to work part time after two weeks for a week, then on to normal time.  Don't rush it.  If people want to help you, have them bring meals you can heat up, and of course cleaning if you're alone.  You won't be able to lift your arms at first, so set things down at your level.   Right after surgery, take something to avoid constipation, I didn't have it with mx, but I had it with the exchange/oopher, and it took forever to go away.  I did start walking as soon as I could, as that was the only exercise I was allowed for awhile.  Walk, walk, walk, it will help you. Hope you breeze through it, Deen

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2009 11:34AM TXBadboob wrote: rebilla, you need to talk to an oncologist to help decide on double masectomy.  I opted for the DMX also, and I had ILC in my left breast only.  I was covered by insurance for the surgery.  Good thing I got both removed, as the path came back and I had IDC and DCIS in my right breast as well!  The nurse you spoke to doesn't sound like she knows what's right about this.  If you will look around the forums, you will see a lot of women who get DMXs with only one side having the cancer.  I also highly recommend a second opinion on all of the treatment decisions.  You DO have time for this, and you don't want to look back on this with any regrets.  Prayers and hugs, Deen

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2010 11:27AM TXBadboob wrote:   It is so nice to know that I am not alone with this problem.  My PS said my arm pain was my shoulders, my age(47), etc.  I still am not sure, as I am on Arimidex and Zometa also, but I remember the pain right after my BMX, thinking they wrenched my arms during surgery, but the pain was minimal, eventually getting worse.   I wanted to let everyone know about this book I checked out from the library:  it is called "The Breast Cancer Survivor's Fitness Plan" by Carolyn M. Kaelin, MD.  In it, they talk about the why's of the pains we are feeling, and suggest the things we can do about them.  They have gentle exercises for every type of surgery and reconstruction, including the frozen shoulder that they say is common after surgery.  They talk a lot about lymphedema and careful things to do about that.  I like it so much I am going to buy it.  Wish I'd known about it after my surgery, as I am a fitness freak and may have overdone myself too soon, hurting myself further.   Hope this helps, and thanks again, Deen
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Pain Syndrome (PMPS) Deeds Lezza13

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2009 08:55AM TXBadboob wrote: This sounds to me like your breasts are very fibrous and dense.  They want to make sure that what they are looking at are lymph nodes, not small tumors.  Each person has a different number of lymph nodes, in different places, so they can't be sure since they can't see well through your dense tissue.  It is good that they are referring to a breast surgeon, since they specialize in this area and will know what to look for and make a decision on what to do.   They may want to do a biopsy on the suspicious mass, which is no big deal, but because of your age, it may be important to find out.  They may just want to monitor you with u/s's or MRIs to keep an eye on it.   Waiting is the hardest part, but please try to keep your mind off of it as much as you can until the time comes.  Saying a prayer for you now! {{{HUGS}}} Deen
